data.title: Über die Spektra des Sauerstoffs (Doppler-Effekt bei Kanalstrahlen). by Stark, Johannes: (1908)
data.meta_description: Soft cover - 1908 - Ann. Phys., 4. Folge, 26. - Leipzig, Johann Ambrosius Barth, 1908, 8°, pp.806-832, orig. Broschur. Rare Offprint! "The paper is an important step toward the theory of structure of the atom. Johann Stark assumed that units of positive electricity are concentrated at certain points on the surface of an atom, with negative electrons outside, from each which lines or tubes of force extended to the positive charge of atoms in combination. Tow atoms are united by electrons common to both." W. Alicke, Foundations of Nuclear Physics and Radio Chemistry, Cat. 263-264, Nr.1064 Partington, Hist. of Chemistry IV, p.948 Johannes Stark (1874-1957) was a German physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1919 "for his discovery of the Doppler effect in canal rays and the splitting of spectral lines in electric fields". This phenomenon is known as the Stark effect. - Über die Spektra des Sauerstoffs (Doppler-Effekt bei Kanalstrahlen).
data.text:
About this Item

Ann. Phys., 4. Folge, 26. - Leipzig, Johann Ambrosius Barth, 1908, 8°, pp.806-832, orig. Broschur. Rare Offprint! "The paper is an important step toward the theory of structure of the atom. Johann Stark assumed that units of positive electricity are concentrated at certain points on the surface of an atom, with negative electrons outside, from each which lines or tubes of force extended to the positive charge of atoms in combination. Tow atoms are united by electrons common to both." W. Alicke, Foundations of Nuclear Physics and Radio Chemistry, Cat. 263-264, Nr.1064 Partington, Hist. of Chemistry IV, p.948 Johannes Stark (1874-1957) was a German physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1919 "for his discovery of the Doppler effect in canal rays and the splitting of spectral lines in electric fields". This phenomenon is known as the Stark effect. Seller Inventory # 11300

Contact seller
